Monoid
A set $M$ with a law of composition $\sigma: M \times M \longrightarrow M$ is called a monoid if $\sigma$ is associative and $M$ admits a unit element with respect to $\sigma$.
Cyclic group
A group $G$ is called cyclic if it is generated by a single element. This is equivalent to the existence of a surjective group homomorphism $\mathbb{Z} \longrightarrow G$.
Ring Extension
The pair (S, R), where S is a subring of R, is called a ring extension.
System of Generators of an Ideal

Let $\mathfrak{a}$ be an ideal of a ring $R$. A family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ of elements in $\mathfrak{a}$ is called a system of generators of $\mathfrak{a}$ if $\mathfrak{a}=\sum_{i \in I} R a_{i}$, i.e., if $\mathfrak{a}$ coincides with the ideal generated by the family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$.
Ring Automorphism
An automorphism of a ring $R$ is an isomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R$.
Finitely generated module
An A-module M is said to be finitely generated if it admits a finite system of generators. It is also referred to as a finite A-module.
Purely Inseparable Extension
A purely inseparable extension is a field extension where the minimal polynomial of any element in the extension has a single root, which is repeated according to the degree of the polynomial.
Degree of a Field Extension

Let $K \subset L$ be a field extension. The vector space dimension $[L: K]:=\operatorname{dim}_{K} L$ is called the degree of $L$ over $K$. The field extension is called finite or infinite, depending on whether $[L: K]$ is finite or infinite.
Trivial Algebraic field extension
An algebraic field extension $L / K$ is trivial if every element of $L$ is algebraic over $K$.
Stabilizer
Let $G \times X \longrightarrow X$ be an action of a group $G$ on a set $X$. The stabilizer or isotropy subgroup of a point $x \in X$ is defined as $G_{x}:=\{g \in G ; g x=x\}$.
r-cycle
A cycle involving $r$ elements is called an $r$-cycle and is denoted as $\pi = (x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r})$.
Definition_Association_Analysis

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: A cyclic group is a specific type of group. Therefore, the concept of a group must be defined to understand what a cyclic group is.
A system of generators of an ideal is defined in terms of an ideal, which in turn is a concept within ring theory. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what an ideal is.
A ring automorphism is an isomorphism of a ring to itself. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what a ring automorphism is.

A finitely generated module is defined in terms of a module, which is a generalization of the concept of a vector space over a ring. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what a module is.
A purely inseparable extension is a specific type of field extension. Therefore, the concept of a field extension must be defined to understand what a purely inseparable extension is.

The degree of a field extension is a measure of the size of the extension, which is a concept within field theory. Therefore, the concept of a field extension must be defined to understand what the degree of a field extension is.

A trivial algebraic field extension is a specific type of algebraic field extension. Therefore, the concept of a field extension must be defined to understand what a trivial algebraic field extension is.
The stabilizer is defined in terms of a group action, which in turn is defined in terms of a group. Therefore, the concept of a group must be defined to understand what a stabilizer is.
An r-cycle is a specific type of permutation, which is a concept within group theory. Therefore, the concept of a group must be defined to understand what an r-cycle is.
